core_concept.principle: Pendulum Period Equations: Simple pendulum: T = 2π√(L/g), Physical pendulum: T = 2π√(I/mgd), Torsional pendulum: T = 2π√(I/κ), Small-angle approximation: sinθ ≈ θ, Reduced length: L_red = I/md
core_concept.explanation: Pendulum periods depend on length and gravitational field for simple pendulums, and on moment of inertia and restoring torque for physical and torsional pendulums, with all exhibiting SHM for small angles.

classifications.note: Simple pendulum: T = 2π√(L/g), Angular frequency: ω = √(g/L), Small-angle: sinθ ≈ θ, Amplitude correction: T ≈ T₀[1 + θ₀²/16] for θ < 30°

principles.statement: Simple pendulums exhibit specific period relationships: Torque Analysis: Restoring torque τ = -mgL sinθ; For small θ: τ ≈ -mgLθ; Rotational form of Hooke's law. Equation of Motion: Iα = τ; mL²(d²θ/dt²) = -mgLθ; d²θ/dt² + (g/L)θ = 0; SHM form. Period Formula: T = 2π/ω = 2π√(L/g); Fundamental result; Time for complete swing. Angular Frequency: ω = √(g/L); Determines oscillation rate; Independent of mass. Small-Angle Approximation: sinθ ≈ θ for θ < 15°; Error < 1% for θ < 15°; Essential for SHM; Exact solution involves elliptic integrals. Amplitude Effects: Period increases with amplitude; Exact period: T = T₀[1 + (1/4)sin²(θ₀/2) + (9/64)sin⁴(θ₀/2) + ...]; 0.1% correction at 5°, 1% at 23°. Mass Independence: Period independent of bob mass; Cancels in derivation; Different masses with same length have same period. Length Dependence: T ∝ √L; Doubling length increases period by √2 ≈ 1.414; Longer pendulums swing slower. Gravity Dependence: T ∝ 1/√g; Stronger gravity gives shorter period; Used to measure g. Energy Perspective: Can derive from energy conservation; Leads to same result.
principles.application: Calculate period from length and gravity. Determine length for desired period. Analyze amplitude effects on period. Apply small-angle approximation. Solve problems using period relationships. Verify mass independence.
principles.example: Calculate grandfather clock pendulum length. Determine pendulum period on different planets. Analyze large-amplitude corrections. Verify period independence from mass.
principles.analogy: Like different length swings on a playground - longer swings take more time for each back-and-forth (longer period), while the weight of the rider doesn't affect the timing, and really high swings take slightly longer than small ones, just like large-amplitude pendulums

worked_examples.title: Basic Period Calculations
worked_examples.problem: A simple pendulum has length 1.2 m. Find its period on Earth (g = 9.80 m/s²). What length would give a 2.0-second period? How would the period change on Mars (g = 3.71 m/s²)?

step_by_step.explanation: Weaker gravity on Mars makes pendulum swing slower; Period increases by 62.5% compared to Earth
A clock designed for Earth would run slow on Mars; Would lose about 37 minutes per hour

worked_examples.final_answer: Earth: T = 2.20 s, Length for 2.0 s period = 0.993 m, Mars: T = 3.57 s; Period depends on √(L/g)

classifications.note: Physical pendulum: T = 2π√(I/mgd), I = moment of inertia about pivot, d = distance from pivot to CM, Reduced length: L_red = I/md, Equivalent to simple pendulum of length L_red

principles.statement: Physical pendulums extend simple pendulum concepts: Physical Pendulum Definition: Any rigid body pivoted to swing freely; Distributed mass; Real-world pendulums. Period Formula: T = 2π√(I/mgd); I = moment of inertia about pivot; d = pivot to center of mass distance; mgd = restoring torque constant. Reduced Length: L_red = I/md; Equivalent simple pendulum length; T = 2π√(L_red/g). Common Configurations: Uniform rod pivoted at end: I = mL²/3, d = L/2, L_red = 2L/3; Uniform disk pivoted at rim: I = 3mR²/2, d = R, L_red = 3R/2. Center of Percussion: Point where impact causes no reaction at pivot; Related to reduced length; Important in sports equipment. Parallel Axis Theorem: I = I_CM + md²; Often needed for arbitrary pivot points; I_CM about center of mass. Compound Pendulums: Multiple masses or complex shapes; May have multiple oscillation modes; Complex period relationships. Kater's Pendulum: Reversible pendulum used to measure g accurately; Two pivot points give same period when L_red same. Applications: Clocks and timing devices; Gravitational field measurements; Mechanical filters; Sports equipment design.

principles.analogy: Like different baseball bats - a bat swung from the handle (physical pendulum) has a specific 'sweet spot' (center of percussion) and swings with a period determined by its mass distribution, equivalent to a simple pendulum of a certain length, while a uniform rod would swing differently

worked_examples.title: Uniform Rod Physical Pendulum
worked_examples.problem: A uniform thin rod of length 1.5 m and mass 0.8 kg is pivoted at one end. Find: (a) period of oscillation, (b) reduced length, (c) period if pivoted at center.

step_by_step.explanation: I_center = mL²/12 = 0.8 × 2.25/12 = 1.8/12 = 0.15 kg·m²; d = 0 (pivot at CM!)
If pivot exactly at CM, d=0, period becomes infinite (no restoring torque); For small offset from center, analyze properly
If pivot distance h from center: I = mL²/12 + mh², d = h, T = 2π√[(L²/12 + h²)/(gh)]
Simple pendulum of same length (1.5 m) would have T = 2π√(1.5/9.8) = 2.46 s; Rod oscillates faster due to mass distribution

worked_examples.final_answer: Pivoted at end: T = 2.01 s, L_red = 1.00 m; Rod equivalent to 1.00 m simple pendulum; Pivot at center requires special analysis

image.caption: Period calculation for uniform rod physical pendulum

worked_examples.title: Disk Pendulum Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A uniform circular disk of radius 0.4 m and mass 1.5 kg is pivoted at a point on its rim. Find the period and reduced length. Compare with a simple pendulum of the same length.

step_by_step.explanation: Using parallel axis theorem: I = I_CM + md² = ½mR² + mR² = 3mR²/2
Simple pendulum of length R = 0.4 m: T = 2π√(0.4/9.8) = 1.269 s; Simple pendulum of length 2R = 0.8 m: T = 1.795 s; Disk period = 1.555 s is between these
Disk oscillates slower than point mass at same distance but faster than if all mass were at center; Reduced length = 1.5R
For disk pivoted at rim: L_red = 3R/2 = 1.5R; Consistent: 1.5 × 0.4 = 0.6 m ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: Period = 1.56 s, Reduced length = 0.60 m; Disk pendulum equivalent to 0.60 m simple pendulum

classifications.note: Torsional pendulum: T = 2π√(I/κ), κ = torsion constant, Applications: T = 2π√(L/g) for timekeeping, g = 4π²L/T² for gravimetry, Foucault pendulum demonstrates Earth's rotation

principles.statement: Torsional pendulums and applications extend pendulum principles: Torsional Pendulum: Rotational oscillation; Restoring torque τ = -κθ; Torsion constant κ; Period: T = 2π√(I/κ). Torsion Constant: κ depends on wire material and dimensions; For thin wire: κ = (πGr⁴)/(2L); G = shear modulus. Comparison with Gravity Pendulums: Different physical principle; No small-angle limitation (for ideal torsion); Period independent of gravity; Used in precision measurements. Timekeeping Applications: Grandfather clocks; Historical time measurement; Pendulum must be very stable; Temperature compensation needed. Gravitational Measurements: g = 4π²L/T²; Measure T accurately to find g; Used in geophysics; Variations detect mineral deposits. Kater's Pendulum: Reversible pendulum; Two pivot points; Adjust until periods equal; Then L_red = distance between pivots; Precise g measurement. Foucault Pendulum: Demonstrates Earth's rotation; Plane of oscillation rotates; Rate: 15°/hour × sin(latitude); Classic demonstration. Other Applications: Seismometers; Inertial navigation; Testing fundamental physics; Educational demonstrations. Modern Uses: Although replaced by quartz and atomic clocks; Still used in some precision instruments; Important for understanding oscillatory motion.

worked_examples.title: Torsional Pendulum Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A torsional pendulum consists of a 0.5 kg disk of radius 0.2 m suspended by a wire with torsion constant 0.8 N·m/rad. Find the period of oscillation.

step_by_step.explanation: If same disk were physical pendulum pivoted at rim: I = 3mR²/2 = 0.03 kg·m², d = R = 0.2 m, T = 2π√(0.03/(0.5×9.8×0.2)) = 2π√(0.03/0.98) = 2π√0.03061 = 1.103 s
Torsional pendulum has shorter period than equivalent gravity pendulum; Different restoring mechanisms
For ideal torsional pendulum, period independent of amplitude; No small-angle approximation needed
Real torsion wires may have non-linear behavior at large angles

worked_examples.final_answer: Period = 0.703 s; Torsional pendulum period depends on √(I/κ)

worked_examples.title: Pendulum Clock Design and Gravitational Measurement
worked_examples.problem: A pendulum clock is designed for Earth (g = 9.80 m/s²) with period 2.00 s. (a) Find the required length. (b) If used on Mars (g = 3.71 m/s²), how much time will it lose per day? (c) What length would give correct time on Mars?

step_by_step.explanation: Clock ticks seconds based on 2.00 s period; On Mars, each actual swing takes 3.251 s; Clock will run slow
Mars day ≈ 24 hours 37 minutes = 88620 s; Number of swings needed: 88620/2.00 = 44310 swings
Time lost = 144050 - 88620 = 55430 s = 15.40 hours slow per day!

step_by_step.step: Length for correct time on Mars

step_by_step.explanation: Mars pendulum must be much shorter: 0.376 m vs 0.993 m on Earth

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Earth length = 0.993 m, (b) Loses 15.4 hours per day on Mars, (c) Mars length = 0.376 m; Pendulum clocks are gravity-dependent

common_misconceptions: Thinking pendulum period depends on bob mass
Believing large-amplitude pendulums have the same period as small ones
Confusing physical pendulums with simple pendulums
Thinking torsional pendulums depend on gravity
Believing pendulum period depends on the material of the bob
Confusing angular displacement with arc length
Thinking all pendulums are simple harmonic oscillators
real_world_applications: Kater's pendulum for precise g measurement
summary: Pendulum period equations describe diverse oscillatory systems: simple pendulums follow T = 2π√(L/g), physical pendulums use T = 2π√(I/mgd) with reduced length L_red = I/md, and torsional pendulums obey T = 2π√(I/κ). All exhibit SHM for small angles, with period independent of mass but dependent on amplitude for large oscillations. Applications span timekeeping (exploiting period constancy), gravimetry (using g = 4π²L/T²), and various scientific instruments. Understanding these relationships enables precise time measurement, gravitational field mapping, and design of oscillatory systems across physics, engineering, and technology.
